clinical_study.brief_title: The Alouette Test in Parkinson Disease
clinical_study.official_title: Screening for Reading Difficulties in Parkinson's Disease: An Evaluation of the Alouette Test

brief_summary.textblock: Reading disorders in Parkinson's Disease (PD) are poorly evaluated due to the lack of validated tests to screen for them. They are often attributed to hand tremors associated with the disease. In this study, the investigating team evaluated the "alouette test" validated for dyslexia screening, in PD by comparing the results to healthy patients.

primary_outcome.description: The Alouette test is based on the precision and speed in reading a short text (279 words). The score corresponds to the total number of words correctly read.

arm_group.description: Patients with Parkinson's Disease (PD) were evaluated for reading disorders using a screening method validated for dyslexia.

arm_group.arm_group_label: Patients without Parkinson's Disease = control group
arm_group.description: Patients without Parkinson's Disease (PD) were evaluated for reading disorders using a screening method validated for dyslexia.

intervention.description: The alouette test was assessed at a fixed distance of 40 centimeters on a fixed surface to avoid errors related to hand tremors.
intervention.arm_group_label: Patients without Parkinson's Disease = control group

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Patients with Parkinson's Disease
- Montreal Cognitive Assessment (MoCA) test > 20
Exclusion Criteria:
- Patient's with supranuclear Palsy
- Other neurologic disease
- Any ophthalmologic disease
- Presence of a nystagmus
- Visual acuity < 0.6
